;在瑞典北部一个昏昏欲睡的沿海城市，欧盟和美国高级官员本周晋级计划为生成式人工智能、电动汽车充电器和 6G 网络等尖端技术制定规则。

;

;但为期两天的会议还表明，盟友对西方主要竞争对手的态度有多么不同

;

;在吕勒奥举行的第四次贸易和技术委员会会议后发布的联合声明中，中国仅被提及两次，此前欧盟谈判代表淡化了华盛顿希望对贸易和技术采取更强硬态度的文本世界第二大经济体。

;

;草案版本抨击北京的“反竞争和有害的非市场政策和做法”。

;

;较为温和的最终文本称，代表团“交换了意见并在欧盟成员国对中国的抨击程度感到不安之后，关于中国在医疗器械领域的非市场做法的信息”。

;

;第二个参考文献称中国“放大了俄罗斯关于战争的虚假信息”在乌克兰，在关于现代信息战对民主社会构成的威胁的部分中。

;

;在活动结束后的新闻发布会上，分歧显而易见：美国官员用热情洋溢的措辞谈论跨大西洋对中国的“趋同”政策，而欧盟同行只是委婉地提到北京。

;

;“实际上，在我们的方法和我们面临的所有主要挑战方面，无论是处理俄罗斯对乌克兰的侵略，我们都有显着的趋同……[或]应对中国带来的一些挑战，”美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯说。

;

;“但我们从完全相同的方法开始，那就是我们都不寻求对抗。我们都不想冷战。而且我们都没有寻求脱钩，”布林肯补充道，并指出最近几周盟友已经使用了相同的语言“去风险化”。

;

;相比之下，欧盟贸易负责人瓦尔迪斯东布罗夫斯基斯和竞争对手负责人玛格丽特·维斯塔格 (Margrethe Vestager) 专注于参与其中的行业，而不是他们所竞争的国家/地区。

;

;“生成式人工智能彻底改变了游戏规则，”维斯塔格说，并宣布欧盟和美国将起草一份草案未来几周该技术的“行为准则”。

;

;“我们正在谈论令人难以置信的技术加速。在这里，我们认为让公民看到民主制度能够实现这一点非常重要，”她补充说。

;

;联合声明在一些热点问题上提到了中国，包括对外投资控制和经济胁迫。

;

;

; p>;

;“清醒但不对抗”：欧盟将调整对华战略

;

;声明称，在投资方面，欧盟和美国“在阻止狭隘的技术进步方面具有共同利益”被评估为增强可能利用这些能力破坏国际和平与安全的行为者的军事和情报能力的核心。”

;

;关于胁迫，该声明含蓄地提到了最近对外国咨询的镇压

;

;合作伙伴提出了“有史以来第一个关于强迫劳动的跨大西洋建议”，旨在从供应链中清除奴隶制，并与工会和商业团体达成一致.

;

;“我们也深切关注针对独立商业尽职调查和咨询公司的行动，这对投资者的信心和商业交易的完整性至关重要，跨大西洋商业界也强调了这一点，”它写道。

;

; p>;

;但语言上的含混表明欧洲正试图在中国问题上保持微妙的平衡。由于担心将北京推向俄罗斯的更近——并紧张地关注明年的美国大选——一些欧盟成员国不愿效仿华盛顿的最大压力策略。

;

;美国官员私下承认这一点，但表示确保最好的方式是确保下届白宫政府保持密切的跨大西洋关系是为了证明这种合作确实在解决中国等问题上取得了成果。

;

;一位不愿透露姓名的美国高级官员表示，华盛顿有信心，欧盟正在“朝着正确的方向”前进，即使没有按照他们希望的速度前进。

;

;尽管如此，该官员承认，欧洲做出的任何有关中国的决定都是自己做出的，而不是由于美国的哄骗——更有可能带来持久的改变。

;

;欧盟正在更新其对华政策，新的经济安全战略将于 6 月 20 日提出，这很可能激发多年来在对外投资审查等领域的政策制定。

;

;欧洲部长们一直表示，即使成员国无法就如何应对中国构成的威胁达成罕见共识，欧盟也已接近达成共识

;

;“我认为美国比欧洲早了几年，但我认为很多国家现在意识到现在不是天真的时候，”瑞典首相乌尔夫克里斯特森周二表示。

;;2023.06.01 00:30;

;中国航天计划的最新发射发生在 5 月 30 日，伴随着长征-2F 火箭载着三名中国宇航员（被称为航天员）前往天宫空间站执行最新的神舟任务。我发现中国航天任务的名称——天宫在汉语中是“天宫”的意思，而神舟是“神器”的意思——以及其他重大科技成果真实地反映了中国文化，同时也传达了一种可以被理解的美丽和意义。

;

;神舟十六号飞船从甘肃省北部的酒泉卫星发射中心升空，不到七个小时就与空间站对接，比载人航天飞机从发射到对接的时间短得多国际空间站任务——这已成为中国航天计划的新常态。

;

;在这次任务中还有几个值得注意的第一次。任务指挥官景海鹏正在第四次进入太空，这是中国航天员的记录。

;

;这次任务的另一个显着发展是，这是中国平民首次——在这次任务中，桂海潮是一名中国航天员。北京航空航天大学的有效载荷专家 - 已经进入太空。中国以前的所有宇航员都来自人民解放军宇航员部队。

;

;中国最近的太空探索获得如此多的媒体关注也就不足为奇了，不仅仅是因为显而易见的原因，例如 2o-靖和桂之间的岁差。对我而言，这是中国向世界其他国家发出的明确信号，表明其和平与民用太空探索、科学与工业开发太空的计划。

;

;这与最新的白皮书一致关于太空——“中国太空计划：2021 年展望”——发表于 2022 年 1 月。该论文首先阐述了中国太空计划的目标：“探索外层空间，扩大人类对地球和宇宙的认识；促进全球就我们在和平利用外层空间和维护外层空间安全造福全人类的共同责任达成共识。” 2014年赴约克大学和多伦多瑞尔森大学做博士后研究员，2017年回到北航任副教授。仅仅六年后，他就上了太空，这至少可以说是一项了不起的壮举.

;

;很明显，中国当局并不担心桂民海在加拿大期间被过度西化。这是一件好事，可以帮助建立未来的信任。

;

;像这样的任务在未来会变得更加普遍。究其原因，中国的空间站是一个承担科学研究的巨大实验室。它能够使用通常复杂而精密的精密设备来举办来自世界各地的广泛的科学和技术实验。

;

;正确校准、操作和修理此类设备需要深刻的理解、技术知识、广泛的研究经验和对科学方法的深刻了解。这些品质通常不会在具有军事背景的成功宇航员中找到。然而，他们在学术界、政府机构和私营部门行业中随处可见。

;

;寻找像桂民海和其他民用宇航员这样的有效载荷专家是中国航天计划未来取得成功的基础。鉴于去年年底中国航天局正在寻求从香港和澳门招募平民申请人，这对香港也具有重要意义。

;

;中国的飞行类人太古机器人已准备好减轻宇航员的工作量

;

;经过严格的选拔程序，中国第四代航天员的候选名单已缩减至约 100 人。多达 14 个名额可供争夺，其中包括从香港和澳门选出的两名有效载荷专家。

;

;最后，大约在神舟十六号准备发射的同时，有消息称中国计划进一步扩大其空间站。天宫现有的三个模块预计将增加一个多功能扩展模块，将其目前的T型排列变成十字型。

;

;这个新节点预计将有多个对接端口，将进一步启用天宫的扩张。最近有传言称中国的空间站可能在十年内接待游客，谁知道届时天宫会有多大和意义重大？

;可能进一步凸显中国经济复苏面临的困难，青年数据创历史新高失业和零售销售低迷、出口和外国直接投资放缓以及通货膨胀率下降将公布 4 月份数据。

;

;不过，也有一些好消息，因为 C919——中国第一架国产窄体客机——完成首次商业飞行，同时中国和澳大利亚的贸易部长在北京会面。

;

;如果您想查看我们的更多报告，请考虑。

;

;

;

;中国第一架自主研发的窄体客机 C919 于周日完成了首次商业飞行。

;

;标志编号 MU9191，该航班由中国东方航空公司运营，载有 130 多名乘客上午 10 点 30 分左右从上海虹桥国际机场起飞，比预定时间提前了大约 10 分钟。

;

;根据来自于的现场直播，这架航班于中午 12 点 30 分降落在北京首都国际机场，受到了礼炮的欢迎。国家广播公司中央电视台。

;

;在经过 14 年的发展之后，在与以美国为首的西方国家的激烈竞争中，中国正在寻求减少对外国技术的依赖，这次飞行时长为两小时。

;

;

;

;5 月份公布的数据显示，4 月份城镇调查失业率降至 5.2%，但 16-24 岁年龄段的失业率创下 20.4% 的历史新高。< /p>;

;“年轻劳动力的失业率上升到 20% 以上，这是一个令人担忧的迹象，”精准资产管理首席经济学家张志伟表示。

;

;什么是中国青年？失业率为何涵盖 16 至 24 岁？

;

;中国的青年失业率主要涵盖 15 至 18 岁的应届高中或职业学校毕业生，以及通常毕业于22 岁左右。

;

;这是北京衡量社会稳定和经济增长的关键指标。

;

;

;

;澳大利亚贸易部长 Don Farrell 会见了中国外长王文涛同意就取消贸易壁垒“加强对话”。

;

;双方在会谈中没有达成任何协议，但王文涛已接受访问澳大利亚的邀请。

;

;会谈几天后，中国驻堪培拉大使表示，中国准备恢复澳大利亚木材的进口，同时还在就澳大利亚总理安东尼·艾博年 (Anthony Albanese) 访问北京进行谈判。

;

;邮报还报道中国外交部长秦刚将于 7 月访问澳大利亚。

;

;不过，在法雷尔访问北京期间，中国并未获得澳大利亚公开支持加入《跨太平洋伙伴关系全面进步协定》，帖子报道。

;

;

;

;4 月份中国零售额同比增长 18.4%，低于 20.2% 的预期增幅，但高于 10.6% 的增幅5 月份公布的数据显示，3 月份的激增主要是由于比较基数较低，因为该数字在去年 4 月份下降了 11.1%。

;

;官方数据显示，4 月份的零售额也比 3 月份下降了 7.8%。

;

;随着青年失业率的恶化，中国 4 月份经济数据的 5 个要点

;

;

;

;在该机构举行就职典礼之前，李云泽被任命为新一届国家金融监管局 (NFRA) 的党委书记。

;

;该机构的成立是在一年一度的“两会”上公布的全面改革计划的一部分” 在北京将金融稳定放在首位的情况下，三月份的议会会议。

;

;李表示，新的监管机构将努力监督所有类型的金融活动，并将寻求消除监管“盲点”并“建立一个铁金融安全墙”。

;

;

;

;尽管去年冠状病毒引起的比较基数较低，但中国 4 月份出口增速放缓，进口放缓进一步加速，增加了新冠疫情后经济复苏的不确定性。

;

;4 月份出口超出预期，同比增长 8.5% 至 2954.2 亿美元，低于 3 月份 14.8% 的惊人增幅， 5 月份表现良好。

;

;与此同时，由于需求疲软，4 月份进口低于预期，同比下降 7.9% 至 2052.1 亿美元，低于 3 月份 1.4% 的降幅

;

;

;

;海南正准备今年首次收获榴莲，预计 6 月份将销售约 2,450 吨（540 万磅）榴莲。< /p>;

;1950 年代，中国种植者开始在海南省种植约 206,000 公顷（510,000 英亩）的热带水果。由于技术加快了生长周期，有望成为岛上主要经济作物的榴莲的种植在 2020 年起飞。

;

;中国将在 6 月吃到第一批本地榴莲。马来西亚和泰国的主导地位是否面临风险？

;

;中国也是东南亚最大的榴莲市场，所谓的榴莲外交已成为泰国、越南和马来西亚等国面临的一个问题。< /p>;

;

;

;5月份公布的数据显示，4月份中国居民消费价格指数（CPI）同比上涨0.1%，而生产者价格指数（PPI）同比下降3.6%

;

;4 月 CPI 创两年多新低，PPI 跌幅创 2020 年 5 月以来最快。

;

;分析人士表示，中国可能面临一段时期通胀温和，预计二季度 CPI 和 PPI 均处于低位，然后在下半年上升。

;

;

;

;尽管北京积极吸引海外投资者作为其政策的一部分5月公布的数据显示，疫情后经济复苏，1-4月实际使用外商直接投资（FDI）735亿美元，同比下降3.3%。

;

;中国由于海外商人的担忧，外国直接投资正在下降

;

;这些数据表明，北京在吸引外国投资者方面还有很多工作要做，外国投资者在中国获得技术、资金和管理专业知识方面发挥着至关重要的作用，尤其是作为与美国的紧张关系持续存在，随着北京以国家安全的名义对金融和尽职调查公司的突击搜查引起了投资者界的担忧。

;

;实际使用的外国投资衡量的是资金的数量中国在与外国公司签订合同时已经收到了。

;

;

;

;中国5月份连续第九个月保持贷款基准利率不变，一年期贷款最优惠利率保持不变(LPR) 稳定在 3.65%，其五年期 LPR 保持在 4.30% 不变。

;

;野村证券将其对中国 2023 年国内生产总值 (GDP) 增长的预测从 5.9% 下调至 5.5%，摩根大通将其全年 GDP 增长预期从 6.4% 下调至 5.9%。

;

;最后，2023 年前四个月中国工业企业的利润同比下降 20.6% ，官方数据显示。

; Thu, 01 Jun 2023 00:20:02 +0800 Chinese tech firms, squeezed in Taiwan over politics, look to expand farther offshorehttps://www.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3222462/chinese-tech-firms-squeezed-taiwan-over-politics-look-expand-farther-offshore?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.05.31 23:00;
;;

;成都微网联盟创始人陈涛正在使用一年一度的Computex台北科技展是该公司开拓海外客户的第一个场所。

;

;他闪闪发光的展览平台位于主要展厅前部的醒目位置，展示了熊猫标本和简体中文显示器——两者都象征着

;

;“政治是一回事，经济是另一回事，”陈说，他指的是台湾与大陆的争端和中美贸易争端。

;

;这位八岁的制作人网络通信设备公司现在选择了 35 个国家作为扩张目标——主要在亚洲、中东和南美洲，因为它已经在中国大陆市场销售了所有可能的产品。

;

;“经济问题是最实用，”他补充道。

;

;台湾下调 2023 年 GDP 预测，但人工智能、可折叠手机和印度提供支持

;

;Micronet Union 是 1,000 多家大陆参展商中的 83 家之一Computex 的总计，NVIDIA 创始人黄仁勋等科技巨头出席了此次活动。然而，与 2019 年参加最近一次完全面对面展会的 297 家大陆参展商相比，大陆参展商的数量大幅下降。

;

;由于政治上的分歧，台湾已经中断与中国大陆的正式对话七年，双方几乎不准出差，现场商务往来困难重重。因此，大陆企业家正在放眼更广阔的世界市场，即使他们在台北仍有业务。

;

;北京认为自治的台湾是一个需要与大陆重新统一的分裂省份，必要时用武力。自时任美国众议院议长南希佩洛西访问该岛以来，紧张局势加剧，这引发了大陆在该岛附近的军事演习。

;

;

;

; Wed, 31 May 2023 23:20:02 +0800 Japan’s chip export controls are a major concern for China’s self-sufficiency campaign, analysts sayhttps://www.scmp.com/tech/article/3222497/japans-chip-export-controls-are-major-concern-chinas-self-sufficiency-campaign-analysts-say?utm_source=rss_feed

;北京敦促日本终止计划中的半导体出口管制，这不足为奇分析师表示，由于东京与美国在贸易限制方面的合作不断加强，中国的芯片行业将面临巨大压力。

;

;根据日本定于 7 月采取的措施，国内公司将需要获得许可证才能销售 23 种芯片芯片制造技术引进国外，包括清洗、沉积、光刻和刻蚀设备。此前，美国、日本和荷兰就限制向中国出口先进芯片制造设备达成协议。

;

;市场研究公司 Counterpoint Research 的半导体分析师 Brady Wang 表示，东京与美国和荷兰将尤其具有破坏性，因为中国寻求采购可用于生产更先进芯片的新半导体设备。

;

;“中国目前有能力生产 14 纳米芯片，但是，它的容量非常有限，”王说。 “鉴于美国和日本的进一步努力，我认为他们没有能力增加 20 纳米及以下 [节点] 的容量。”

;

;纳米是用于测量的常用度量单位对半导体行业技术进行分类，纳米越少通常意味着技术越先进。韩国三星电子和台积电宣布2022年投产3纳米芯片。

;

;目前，销售用于生产尖端芯片设备的最大公司在美国、荷兰和日本，如美国的应用材料公司、荷兰的ASML和日本的东京电子。根据联合国商品贸易数据库的数据，日本是 2022 年对中国最大的半导体制造设备出口国。

;

;随着七国集团采取行动削减中国业务，日本吸引全球芯片制造商

;

;不过，布雷迪说日本出口管制措施的具体影响还有待观察，中日两国尚需时间制定一些豁免条款。 The US Department of Commerce gave South Korea's SK Hynix and Samsung one-year exemptions on existing export controls, which are set to expire in October.

;

;Japan, similar to the Netherlands, has not explicitly referenced China in its export control announcements. Instead, Tokyo officials have said that the exports fall under the Foreign Exchange and Foreign Trade Act, which regulates the export of Japanese weapons and other goods that can be converted into military applications.

;

;Still, Chinese officials and some experts have seen Japan's plans as a signal that Tokyo is following the US lead in the semiconductor trade war, placing long-term strategic rivalry over short-term economic cost.

;

;At the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference in Detroit last Friday, which included members from 21 economies in the Pacific Rim, Chinese Commerce Minister Wang Wentao reportedly opposed Japan's export curbs. A statement from the minister on Monday called the policy a wrongful practice that “seriously damaged” international economic and trade rules and seriously damaged the foundation of industrial development.

;

;Meanwhile, at the conference, Japan's Minister of Economy, Trade and Industry Yasutoshi Nishimura and his US counterpart Gina Raimondo agreed to further boost cooperation on the development of the world's next-generation of semiconductors.

;

;A joint statement released by Japan's ministry and the US commerce secretary on Monday said they would encourage semiconductor research centres of the two countries to work together in creating a road map for the development of technology and human resources associated with chips.

;

;The agreement also followed a three-day G7 Summit held in Hiroshima earlier in May, in which Japan and US officials agreed to “de-risk” rather than “decouple” from China's economy, emphasising semiconductor supply chain security.

;

;Asked about Japan and the US's cooperation agreements on Monday, Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning said “it is China's consistent belief that the cooperation between countries should not target any third party, and we oppose putting up exclusionary blocs and engaging in discriminatory and exclusive cooperation”.

;

;While Japan's controls could restrict some sales by major Japanese companies such as Nikon, and Tokyo Electron, Trade Minister Nishimura has stated that they will have a limited impact on domestic corporate earnings.

;

;In an earnings report in March, Tokyo Electron said about 24 per cent of its sales in 2023 came from China, a decrease of 2 per cent from the previous year. However, the company expects that sales in China will exceed 30 per cent in 2024 due to the growing mature node market in China.

;

;Mature nodes are generally defined as less advanced chips, above 28-nm, which require older manufacturing processes. Since being put on the US entity list for export controls in 2020, China's largest chip maker Semiconductor Manufacturing International Corporation (SMIC) has ramped up production of mature nodes, posting record revenue in 2022.

;

;SMIC is able to produce 14-nm chips, but US trade restrictions have paused plans to mass produce chips below the critical 10-nm threshold, which is commonly used for producing advanced chips for smartphones and tablets.

;

;Meanwhile, China has been pouring money into advanced chip technology research and development. Earlier this year, there was speculation that Huawei Technologies Co was working on tools related to chip hardware and software that can produce 14-nm chips.

;

;However, according to a report from Counterpoint's research director Richard Windsor, there has been no indication that the Shenzhen-based giant can do so at the volume and yield needed to be economically viable.

;Last year was a mixed bag pay-wise for the women who run companies in the S&P 500 – compensation increased for more than half of them, but the median pay package fell 6 per cent.

;

;Of the 343 CEOs in the compensation survey of S&P 500 companies done by the AP and Equilar, only 20 were women. Because they are a small group, changes in pay for only a few can easily skew the overall figures.

;

;Australia's biggest companies must now reveal gender pay gap yearly

;

;The drop comes after a 26 per cent jump in the value of pay packages for female CEOs in 2021, a year when compensation reflected a recovering economy and soaring stock prices and profits. Many chief executives were rewarded for steering their companies through the worst of the pandemic.

;

;Overall, female CEOs saw their performance bonuses fall 13 per cent to US$2.8 million last year and stock awards fall 4 per cent to an average of US$10 million. Their median total compensation fell 6 per cent to US$14.7 million. The median pay for male CEOs rose 1 per cent to US$14.8 million.

;

;“We still do not have enough women CEOs,” said Lorraine Hariton, President & CEO of Catalyst, a non-profit organisation focused on women in the workplace. “It's hard to make a comment about pay when we really don't have a big enough sample size.”

;

;Lisa Su, CEO of Advanced Micro Devices, was the highest paid female CEO in the AP survey for the fourth year in a row, but she slipped to 26th highest paid overall, from 22nd last year. Su was the highest paid of all CEOs, men and women, in 2019.

;

;The AP's and Equilar's compensation study included pay data for 343 CEOs at S&P 500 companies who have served at least two financial years at their companies, which filed proxy statements between January 1 and April 30.

;

;Some notable female CEOs were not included because they became CEO less than two years ago or their companies file proxy statements at a different time, including Roz Brewer at Walgreens Boots Alliance, Jane Fraser at Citigroup and Linda Rendle at Clorox.

;

;Most of a CEO's pay package consists of stock and stock options awards. At AMD, stock awards and options made up more than 90 per cent of Su's pay. Her total pay package of US$30.2 million was up 2 per cent from her package the previous year.

;

;Nasdaq's CEO Adena Friedman received the biggest pay rise, a 40 per cent jump. That was mostly due to a performance-based share option award with a value of US$10 million, associated with the renewal of her employment agreement for an additional five years. Half of the share option award will become available after five years of employment, and half will be awarded if Friedman reaches an earnings target in five years. Her total pay package is valued at US$28 million.

;

;Executives could see steeper pay cuts in 2023 when boards consider the full effect of the stock market's downturn, said Kelly Malafis, a partner at Compensation Advisory Partners, a consulting firm that works with boards. The S&P 500 fell nearly 20 per cent in 2022.

; Wed, 31 May 2023 22:20:02 +0800 Chinese envoy’s Europe trip a ‘search for common ground’ on Ukraine war, analysts sayhttps://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3222450/chinese-envoys-europe-trip-search-common-ground-ukraine-war-analysts-say?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;China's special envoy for Eurasian affairs Li Hui wrapped up a 12-day European tour that took him to Ukraine, Poland, France, Germany, Brussels and Russia on a mission to make clear Beijing's position on the Ukraine war.

;

;Observers said the main purpose of Li's trip, which concluded on Friday, appeared to be a search for common ground between China and Europe in their approaches towards the war, and while his talks were unlikely to bring about a ceasefire, the tour had raised Beijing's profile as a peace broker in the conflict.

;

;Li's first stop was Kyiv, where he met Ukrainian leader Volodymyr Zelensky and other key officials. He told them there was no panacea for the war and urged all parties to create conditions for peace talks.

;

;Ukraine's foreign minister told Li that Kyiv would not accept any proposals for ending the war that involved losing territory or freezing the conflict, according to the country's foreign ministry.

;

;Li's visit came less than a month after a highly anticipated call between Zelensky and Chinese President Xi Jinping.

;

;China's peace envoy pushes political settlement for Ukraine in Moscow meetings

;

;The Chinese envoy, who served as Beijing's ambassador to Russia for a decade, ended his trip in Moscow, where Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov welcomed China's “balanced” position on the crisis. The two countries also pledged to boost ties and improve communications on a political solution to the war.

;

;Chinese foreign ministry spokeswoman Mao Ning said on Monday that Beijing would continue to “encourage the international community to find the broadest common understandings” and contribute to a “political settlement to the Ukraine crisis”.

;

;“At present, the Ukraine crisis is still at a critical juncture,” she said.

;

;Experts said Beijing would be pleased with the results of Li's trip, but they also struck a cautionary note about the chances of a breakthrough deal any time soon.

;

;“Li Hui merely serves as a forerunner in paving the way for greater, more substantive, involvement by the Chinese leadership in the future to broker peace,” said James Char, a research fellow with the China programme at the S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies in Singapore.

;

;He said the prospect of the war ending soon was “unlikely” as the two sides disagreed about the territory that had been occupied and whether to freeze the conflict.

;

;Sourabh Gupta, a senior fellow at the Institute for China-America Studies in Washington, said the expectations for Li's visit to Europe were low, and “he certainly did not exceed them”.

;

;However, that should not be viewed as a failure, according to Gupta. “To the contrary, the basic purpose of the visit, which was served, was to formally familiarise his counterparts with China's 12-point position … and offer China's good offices,” he said.

;

;“The purpose was not to bring back quick results, which in any case is not feasible at this time.”

;

;Beijing in February put forward a vague peace proposal that called for a ceasefire and peace talks, among other things.

;

;“At this time, Li's trip was primarily a familiarisation exercise and an occasion to hear out the views of his European counterparts, and in this regard the basic objective was accomplished,” Gupta added.

;

;Alfred Wu, an associate professor at the National University of Singapore's Lee Kuan Yew School of Public Policy, suggested that the visit would give Beijing some credibility, especially on the back of recent interactions between Xi and leaders from Russia and Ukraine.

;

;He added that Li's six-leg tour was intended to bridge the gap between the European and Chinese approaches towards finding a solution to the war.

;

;“My own feeling is that the gap between Europe and China is very, very big,” Wu said. “It's not about how to rally support from Europe but to mitigate the differences between China and Europe.”

;

;China peace envoy told again Beijing must push Moscow to end Ukraine invasion

;

;Wang Yiwei, an international relations professor at Renmin University in Beijing, said the trip proved that China was “actively mediating” and that there were positive signs of Ukraine slowly warming up to Beijing's efforts.

;

;“There is a certain consensus now. After the trip, Ukraine now feels that China is not what they have imagined, and that China is not on the side of Russia and is indeed neutral,” he said.

;

;China has been trying to portray itself as a neutral party in the conflict, but Western nations have been sceptical of its efforts because of Beijing's close ties with Moscow and its reluctance to condemn Russia's actions.

;

;Wang said he was hopeful that China's efforts would prove to be successful, and that the two countries would eventually move towards peace talks.

;

;But Gupta noted that China was a “marginal player” within the European security architecture, so its capacity to underwrite a peace deal in Ukraine was limited.

;

;“The only instance in which China could potentially play an outsized role is if the portents for a cessation of hostilities or a ceasefire [are] high and key Western European players are willing to rein Kyiv in and deliver it to the negotiating table,” he said.

;

;Gupta said Li's trip would not make or break China's status as an “honest broker”, nor would it sway Europeans one way or another on Beijing's peacemaking efforts.

;

;“All told, China came out with a better look, albeit just marginally, from its diplomatic foray into European peacemaking. And there are many chapters to be written as yet on the overall peacemaking front,” he said.

;

;Poland pushes Chinese peace envoy for Russian withdrawal

;

;Reuters on Tuesday quoted Ukraine's chief diplomatic adviser Ihor Zhovkva as saying that the only way to end the war would be with Ukraine's peace plan, which required the full withdrawal of Russian troops.

;

;“There cannot be a Brazilian peace plan, a Chinese peace plan, a South African peace plan when you are talking about the war in Ukraine,” Zhovkva said.

;

;Gupta said if the view in Europe was that China should use its economic leverage to compel Russia to withdraw from Ukraine, it would remain “just a pipe dream”.

;

;Citing Western officials, The Wall Street Journal reported last week that Li's message in Europe was that countries should urge an immediate ceasefire and leave Russia in possession of the territories it now occupied in Ukraine.

;

;Ukrainian Foreign Minister Dmytro Kuleba rejected the report, saying he had contacted relevant European officials in the countries Li visited, and “none of them” confirmed that Li had proposed recognising the Russian-occupied territories.

;

;In the report, a diplomat was quoted as saying that one of China's main interests was ensuring that Russia did not lose the war.

;

;Wu said Li's – and China's – position was within expectations, but he believed Europe would reject any proposal for Moscow to keep occupied territory.

;

;“For Europe, the bottom line is very clear. This is an invasion and Russia should withdraw from Ukraine,” he said. “China made its position much clearer and the differences between Europe and China have become larger out of this visit.”

;He would also bring a more traditional Republican message to the nomination battle: He has been critical of Trump and Florida Governor Ron DeSantis for their failure to offer full-throated support for Ukraine in its efforts to combat Russia's invasion and says he will take a harder line on federal spending – including entitlements.

;

;But Christie's entry also grows the Republican field to no fewer than seven major announced candidates – with several more still in the wings – potentially bolstering Trump's divide-and-conquer strategy.

;

;As a one-time Trump rival-turned-loyalist who is an adversary again, Christie would occupy a unique spot within the growing field of Republican challengers. He has denounced Trump's behaviour since the 2020 presidential election, and said other challengers in the field were simply trying to be “Trump Lite”.

;

;“We've watched a number of declared candidates – and almost declared candidates now – who all seem to really not know what to do with him. They kind of cosy up to him. They hope that he implodes, and that if they are nice to him, that they'll inherit his voters,” Christie said on ABC News, where he is a paid political commentator. “You can't beat Donald Trump by playing bumper pool.”

;

;With the Trump-vs.-DeSantis rivalry grabbing the headlines, other candidates have struggled to get traction in polls. Former United Nations Ambassador Nikki Haley, businessman Vivek Ramaswamy, South Carolina Senator Tim Scott and former Arkansas Governor Asa Hutchinson are all polling under 5 per cent. ;

;That expansive field of candidates could work to Trump's advantage, repeating the dynamic that helped him secure the nomination seven years ago. As the anti-Trump vote was split among several candidates, Trump was able to rack up delegates in winner-take-all state primaries with less than a majority of the vote.

;

;Christie was part of that 2016 scrum, dropping out of the race after a poor showing in New Hampshire and becoming the first major candidate to endorse Trump. He then helped Trump prepare for debates in 2016 and 2020 – standing in for Hillary Clinton and Joe Biden in mock debate sessions – and served as chairman of Trump's presidential transition team in 2016.

;

;A Christie campaign would likely be well financed. Christie has close ties to New York Mets owner Steve Cohen, who helped fund Christie's super-PAC in 2016 and put him on the baseball team's board of directors.

;

;Known for a brash style, Christie served two terms as governor of New Jersey, a time that bridged the rise of the Tea Party after President Barack Obama's election to Trump's populist-driven campaign and first year in office.

;

;The culmination of that combative governing style came in the “Bridgegate” scandal, in which three state officials were convicted or pleaded guilty to conspiracy and fraud-related charges for deliberately closing lanes connecting to the George Washington Bridge to cause a traffic jam in retribution against a Democratic mayor.

;

;The Supreme Court later overturned two of the convictions, ruling that the lane closures were motivated by “political payback” but “not every corrupt act by state or local officials is a federal crime”.

;

;Christie denied having any knowledge of the plot but later said he believed the controversy was a factor in Trump's decision to pick Pence over Christie as his running mate.

;French video gaming giant Ubisoft Entertainment, the publisher behind hit action-adventure franchise Assassin's Creed, is set to close its official online store in mainland China, as the company ceases direct merchandise sales in the industry's largest market.

;

;Ubisoft's flagship store on Tmall, the e-commerce platform owned by Alibaba Group Holding, will halt sales from next Wednesday, following a “strategic adjustment” to “no longer operate its merchandise sales business in China”, the company announced last Friday via its official account on Chinese microblogging platform Weibo. Alibaba owns the South China Morning Post.

;

;“Following a review of our collectibles and merchandising products strategy in China, we have decided to stop our direct sales in the country,” a representative from Ubisoft China said in a statement to the Post on Wednesday.

;

;Still, the Tencent Holdings-backed company said it remains committed to the Chinese market. “We will continue to launch products in collaboration with licensing partners, and these will be available on the sales channels of our partners,” the statement said.

;

;Ubisoft saw its revenue decline during its past financial year ended March, which company chairman and chief executive Yves Guillemot described as a “challenging year” that has prompted cost-reduction efforts. It posted an operating loss of €500.2 million (US$536.1 million), as net bookings declined 18 per cent to €1.739 billion from the previous financial year.

;

;At present, Ubisoft's Tmall store offers a variety of merchandise, ranging from apparel priced under 100 yuan to so-called garage kits that each cost more than 2,000 yuan. These products are based on some of the company's popular video game franchises, including Assassin's Creed, Tom Clancy's and Just Dance.

;

;The company's move to discontinue its direct merchandise sales on the mainland comes ahead of China's annual “618” shopping festival on June 18, the country's second most important e-commerce event after Singles' Day in November.

;

;It also reflects a trend among major foreign video gaming companies to withdraw from China, where the industry is tightly regulated.

;

;China's gamers bid farewell as Blizzard ends World of Warcraft service

;

;US publisher Blizzard Entertainment, a subsidiary of video game holding company Activision Blizzard, suspended on January 24 the operations of World of Warcraft and its other popular online games on the mainland, following failed talks with NetEase for a six-month extension of their licensing agreement.

;

;American developer Epic Games, the studio behind online survival-battle-royale-and sandbox game Fortnite, shut down that title's operations in China in November 2021 after local partner Tencent failed to get a licence to officially launch the game in the country.

;

;Although Ubisoft announced the launch of various promotions ahead of its online store's closure, Chinese players took to social media to express their disappointment following the announcement.

;

;“It came as a surprise to me as the store has been operating for quite some time,” said Richard Pan, a 25-year-old Ubisoft player based in Shanghai. “Although it does not affect Ubisoft's game publishing in China, it still made me worry if something similar to Blizzard's exit will happen.”

;

;“I feel very sad about the closure,” said Assassin's Creed fan Fu Meng, who has so far spent over 3,400 yuan in Ubisoft's Tmall store. “If I want to buy Ubisoft merchandise in the future, especially the newly-released ones, it will be much more difficult.”
